OUR MISTAKE
For years the NEWS-LETTER, and the undergraduate body in general, have been laboring under an erroneous impression. Editor after
editor has bequeathed to his successor the belief that graduates of Baltimore high schools head the list of failures at Hopkins. And there
has always been a tradition existing that products of private schools
were paragons of scholastic ability, and that but comparatively few of
their number were ever ejected by means of the automatic "three-failure
route."
In a recent editorial the NEWS-LETTER stated that "the greatest
number of failures . . . . occur among graduates of city high schools.
Next in line are entrants from county schools, while the least number
of failures are registered among men from private institutions."
The NEWS-LETTER desires to correct this assertion. Figures presented in President Goodnow's recent report demonstrate conclusively
that the percentage of failures is lowest/among graduates of Baltimore
high schools.- Men from county high schools stand next, while the least
efficient students, from the point of view of scholastic achievement, are
those from private institutions. The NEWS-LETTER regrets this error
and we regret the fact that we and our editorial antecedents have been
responsible for the instigation and promulgation of this false tradition.
The News-Letter wishes to announce the election of Mr. Alfred J.
McKay,'25, as Advertising Manager for 1924-25.

Delivers Fourth of De Lamar
Lectures

OF BALTIMORE

Professor M. W. Pullen Gives Illustrated
Lecture to Electrical Club in
M. E. Building

"The electrification of steam
railroads has been proved by tests
made by the Westinghouse Electric and other large electrical corporations to be both economical
and efficient," declared Professor
M. W. Pullen, in an illustrated address before the members of the
Johns Hopkins Electrical Club.
Mr. Pullen spoke on "Steam Railroad Electrification" at the regular
meeting of the club, held last Friday, January 11, in the Mechanical Engineering Building.
Electric System's Advantages

The speaker recounted many advantages which the electric railway holds over its steam rival. In
the first place, it will haul heavy
(loads over the steep grades of
mountainous districts at twice the
speed, and much more efficiently,
especially in cold weather. In
fact, the electric engine is actually
more efficient in cold weather than
in warm. Secondly, the brake
movements are not only at greater
speed, but the braking System operates with more security, especially on down grades.
Professor Pullen presented authoritative data from some of the
largest railroad systems in the
country, which conclusively proved
the economies which the installation of electric locomotives and
trains brought about. According
to officers of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, their
company has saved $22,000 on new
brake shoes alone since the system
was electrified. Another instance
of saving was in their switching
system. In this department six
electric locomotives easily do the
work that formerly required ten
steam locomotives.
Monster Electric Engine

Dr. Hans Zinsser, professor of
bacteriology at the Medical School
of the Harvard University, was
the speaker at the fourth De Lamar Lecture in Hygiene, given at
the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and lublic Health, Dr.
Zinsser, who is one of the foremost authorities on bacteriology
and allied subjects in the present
age, spoke on "The Present State
of Knowledge of Hypersusceptibility."
The Harvard professor told of
the present limited knowledge in
this important subject in the field
of hygiene, and recounted the
progress which investigators are
now making in research work. The
advancing of knowledge in this
subject was declared. by Dr. Zinsser to be of vital importance in
public health work.
The De Lamar Lectureship in
Hygiene is one which has been
given annually at the School of
Hygiene and Public Health at
Johns Hopkins for some years.
During the present scholastic year
several authorities on public health
work have been brought to Baltimore to address these meetings,
which are all public and do not
require cards of admission.
AERONAUTICAL ENGINEERS
NEEDED BY GOVERNMENT
Dr. John B. Whitehead, dean of
the Engineering School, has received notice from the United
States Civil Service Commission
that applications will now be received from graduates of recognized engineering- schools for positions as junior mechanical engineers.
Men selected will specialize in
aeronautical work and, as construction in this field is continually expanding at present, they have
opportunty of rising to the rank of
aeronautical engineer. The salary
will be $7.20 per day to start. The
majority of the engineers selected
will be placed in the Engine Test
Laboratory, the Navy Yard,
Washington, D. C.
Applicants should apply immediately to the United States Civil
Service Commission, Washington,
D. C., asking for Form 1312.

The speaker further gave interesting figures as to the size of the
largest electric engine' in use today. This locomotive, which is the
property of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, has six
pairs of driving wheels, and develops 4.200 horse power at a
speed of 65 miles an hour. This
locomotive is capable of pulling a

This afternoon, the Naturalists'
Field Club, an organization open
to all, will make a trip to the famous crow's nest near Halethorpe
for the purpose of observing the
birds in that particular place,
which is recorded to have existed
since the earliest colonial times.
Here several thousand crows,
which forage during the day, assemble to spend the night. The
club hopes to obtain some photographs as well as to observe the
winter roosting habits of the
crows. Those making the trip
are requested to bring their field
0-lasses and cameras.
6
The start will be made at 4
P. M.from Room 11, Gilman Hall,
and the party will return to Baltimore not later than 6.30 P. M.
The expedition, which promises to
be one of the most interesting held
thus far will be under the direction of Dr. Cowles.

UNDECEIVED
I worshiped a star
From so very far
That I took it to be an eye,
And I blew a kiss
Thru a cloud of mist
To a moonbeam, gliding by;
And I thought I had reached the
highest peak of the universe's pride,
And I thought I had mounted
where, uncounted, the
paragons must hide.
By chance, I found
On heavenly ground
A soft, strayed southerly breeze,
And a rose's scent
—0, hardly spent—
And the consummate blue of
the seas;
And I thought I was there in the
purest of air that the human mind believes,
And I thought I had found the holiest ground that the human mind conceives.
How could I know
In this world below
There was something equally
rare?
The fresh, young kiss
Of that radiant miss
Is a marvel beyond compare;
And I wonder to think how near
the brink I was to great
despair,
And I wonder to know that awhile
ago the earth was springless and bare!
H. S. G., '26.

OUR MISTAKE
For years the NEWS-LETTER, and the undergraduate body in general, have been laboring under an erroneous impression. Editor after
editor has bequeathed to his successor the belief that graduates of Baltimore high schools head the list of failures at Hopkins. And there
has always been a tradition existing that products of private schools
were paragons of scholastic ability, and that but comparatively few of
their number were ever ejected by means of the automatic "three-failure
route."
In a recent editorial the NEWS-LETTER stated that "the greatest
number of failures . . . . occur among graduates of city high schools.
Next in line are entrants from county schools, while the least number
of failures are registered among men from private institutions."
The NEWS-LETTER desires to correct this assertion. Figures presented in President Goodnow's recent report demonstrate conclusively
that the percentage of failures is lowest/among graduates of Baltimore
high schools.- Men from county high schools stand next, while the least
efficient students, from the point of view of scholastic achievement, are
those from private institutions. The NEWS-LETTER regrets this error
and we regret the fact that we and our editorial antecedents have been
responsible for the instigation and promulgation of this false tradition.
The News-Letter wishes to announce the election of Mr. Alfred J.
McKay,'25, as Advertising Manager for 1924-25.

Professor M. W. Pullen Gives Illustrated
Lecture to Electrical Club in
M. E. Building

"The electrification of steam
railroads has been proved by tests
made by the Westinghouse Electric and other large electrical corporations to be both economical
and efficient," declared Professor
M. W. Pullen, in an illustrated address before the members of the
Johns Hopkins Electrical Club.
Mr. Pullen spoke on "Steam Railroad Electrification" at the regular
meeting of the club, held last Friday, January 11, in the Mechanical Engineering Building.
Electric System's Advantages

The speaker recounted many advantages which the electric railway holds over its steam rival. In
the first place, it will haul heavy
(loads over the steep grades of
mountainous districts at twice the
speed, and much more efficiently,
especially in cold weather. In
fact, the electric engine is actually
more efficient in cold weather than
in warm. Secondly, the brake
movements are not only at greater
speed, but the braking System operates with more security, especially on down grades.
Professor Pullen presented authoritative data from some of the
largest railroad systems in the
country, which conclusively proved
the economies which the installation of electric locomotives and
trains brought about. According
to officers of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, their
company has saved $22,000 on new
brake shoes alone since the system
was electrified. Another instance
of saving was in their switching
system. In this department six
electric locomotives easily do the
work that formerly required ten
steam locomotives.
Monster Electric Engine

Dr. Hans Zinsser, professor of
bacteriology at the Medical School
of the Harvard University, was
the speaker at the fourth De Lamar Lecture in Hygiene, given at
the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and lublic Health, Dr.
Zinsser, who is one of the foremost authorities on bacteriology
and allied subjects in the present
age, spoke on "The Present State
of Knowledge of Hypersusceptibility."
The Harvard professor told of
the present limited knowledge in
this important subject in the field
of hygiene, and recounted the
progress which investigators are
now making in research work. The
advancing of knowledge in this
subject was declared. by Dr. Zinsser to be of vital importance in
public health work.
The De Lamar Lectureship in
Hygiene is one which has been
given annually at the School of
Hygiene and Public Health at
Johns Hopkins for some years.
During the present scholastic year
several authorities on public health
work have been brought to Baltimore to address these meetings,
which are all public and do not
require cards of admission.
AERONAUTICAL ENGINEERS
NEEDED BY GOVERNMENT
Dr. John B. Whitehead, dean of
the Engineering School, has received notice from the United
States Civil Service Commission
that applications will now be received from graduates of recognized engineering- schools for positions as junior mechanical engineers.
Men selected will specialize in
aeronautical work and, as construction in this field is continually expanding at present, they have
opportunty of rising to the rank of
aeronautical engineer. The salary
will be $7.20 per day to start. The
majority of the engineers selected
will be placed in the Engine Test
Laboratory, the Navy Yard,
Washington, D. C.
Applicants should apply immediately to the United States Civil
Service Commission, Washington,
D. C., asking for Form 1312.

speed of 65 miles an hour. This

This afternoon, the Naturalists'
Field Club, an organization open
to all, will make a trip to the famous crow's nest near Halethorpe
for the purpose of observing the
birds in that particular place,
which is recorded to have existed
since the earliest colonial times.
Here several thousand crows,
which forage during the day, assemble to spend the night. The
club hopes to obtain some photographs as well as to observe the
winter roosting habits of the
crows. Those making the trip
are requested to bring their field
0-lasses and cameras.

be one of the most interesting held
thus far will be under the direction of Dr. Cowles.

UNDECEIVED
I worshiped a star
From so very far
That I took it to be an eye,
And I blew a kiss
Thru a cloud of mist
To a moonbeam, gliding by;
And I thought I had reached the
highest peak of the universe's pride,
And I thought I had mounted
where, uncounted, the
paragons must hide.
By chance, I found
On heavenly ground
A soft, strayed southerly breeze,
And a rose's scent
—0, hardly spent—
And the consummate blue of
the seas;
And I thought I was there in the
purest of air that the human mind believes,
And I thought I had found the holiest ground that the human mind conceives.
How could I know
In this world below
There was something equally
rare?
The fresh, young kiss
Of that radiant miss
Is a marvel beyond compare;
And I wonder to think how near
the brink I was to great
despair,
And I wonder to know that awhile
ago the earth was springless and bare!
H. S. G., '26.
